debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: Delivering Homes, Building Communities 2025-2030: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage

speech.p: I would like to advise members of the constitutional requirement that members must be physically present within the confines of the Leinster House complex in order to be participate in meetings. The Government published its new national housing plan, Delivering Homes, Building Communities: An Action Plan on Housing Supply and Targeting Homelessness 2025-30 on 13 November last. It commits to delivering 300,000 homes by 2030, including 72,000 social homes. Today I am pleased to have the opportunity to consider the new housing plan with the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage, Deputy James Browne, and his officials from the Department.

Before we start, I wish to explain some limitations to parliamentary privilege and the practices of the Houses as regards references you may make to one another in your evidence. The evidence of witnesses physically present or who give evidence from within the parliamentary precinct is protected pursuant to the Constitution and statute by absolute privilege. Witnesses are again reminded of the long-standing parliamentary practice that you should not criticise or make charges against any person or entity by name or in any such way as to make him, her or it identifiable or otherwise engage in speech that might be regarded as damaging to the good name of the person or entity. Therefore, if your statements are potentially defamatory in relation to an identifiable person or entity, you will be directed to discontinue your remarks and it is imperative that you comply with any such direction.

The opening statement has been circulated to members. I invite the Minister to make his opening remarks. Is it agreed among members that we will publish the statement after the meeting? Agreed. I call the Minister.

speech.from: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage (Deputy James Browne)
speech.p: I thank the Cathaoirleach for the opportunity to address the committee today. Housing remains the defining social and economic challenge of our time. It impacts families, communities, our workforce and our national competitiveness. That is why the Government’s new plan, Delivering Homes, Building Communities, reaffirms housing as the number one priority for every arm of government, national and local, and sets out a clear, ambitious and realistic path to the delivery of the homes people need.

This plan builds on the progress already made under Housing for All. Over 137,000 new homes have been built, 44,000 social homes have been delivered and nearly 16,900 affordable supports have been provided, including more than 4,500 cost-rental homes, a tenure type that did not even exist five years ago. These achievements give us a strong foundation. However, now we must do more and we must do it faster.

Under Delivering Homes, Building Communities, we are targeting 300,000 new homes by 2030. This is not a ceiling; it is a floor. If we can deliver more, we will. Increased supply is the single most effective way to moderate price growth, improve affordability, tackle homelessness and allow more people to put down roots in communities. The plan is built on the two pillars of activating supply and supporting people. Activating supply means removing the structural barriers that have slowed housing delivery for too long. Those include barriers in planning, infrastructure, land availability, regulation, skills and finance. A major driver of this is the largest public capital investment programme in the history of the State. Over the next decade, €275 billion will be invested, ensuring delivery of the infrastructure needed for housing. To ensure this investment translates into actual homes on the ground, the Government has established the housing activation office. It is up and running and already engaging with all local authorities and industry. Its task is simple: to identify and remove blockages so land can be activated and homes can be built without delay.

We are also reforming the planning system through the implementation of the Planning and Development Act 2024, providing certainty, clearer timelines and better outcomes. A revised national planning framework has already allowed the zoning of significantly more land. Across government, the work of the accelerating infrastructure task force will work alongside these measures to ensure there is a pipeline of zoned, serviced land in place to support housing delivery over the lifetime of this plan.

To boost viability, especially for apartments, the Government has introduced a suite of complementary measures that could reduce the delivery cost of apartments by up to €160,000 per unit, unlocking developments that were stalled only months ago. Increasing skills and capacity is also essential. That is why we are doubling investment in Enterprise Ireland’s built-to-innovate programme, supporting the adoption of modern methods of construction and ensuring at least 25% of social and affordable homes will use these faster, more efficient building techniques. To support SME builders, the backbone of housing delivery in many areas, the Government has approved €400 million in ISIF equity investment for homebuilding and €200 million more for Home Building Finance Ireland.

The second pillar of our plan is ensuring that the homes we build meet the needs of all our people. Homelessness, particularly child homelessness, remains one of the most urgent issues facing the State. Delivering Homes, Building Communities recognises that we must both increase supply of housing and tackle the root causes of homelessness to be successful. We reaffirm our commitment to the Lisbon declaration to work towards ending homelessness by 2030. We will implement a child and family homelessness action plan and a homelessness prevention framework. We are providing an additional €100 million in capital funding in 2026 to help families to exit emergency accommodation.

The most powerful tool we have, however, is the delivery of social housing. Over the lifetime of the plan, we will provide 72,000 new-build social homes and provide 90,000 affordable supports. In 2026 alone, over €9 billion in capital funding will support social and affordable delivery through the Exchequer, the Land Development Agency, LDA, and the Housing Finance Agency. We are also tackling vacancy and dereliction head-on, through the expanded vacant property refurbishment grant, the extended living city initiative and a new derelict sites tax. These measures will bring thousands of homes back into use, revitalising our villages, towns and cities.

The plan recognises the changing needs of our population. An action plan for housing for older people will support right-sizing options and increase the delivery of suitable homes. Funding for the enhanced housing adaptation grant for older people and disabled people has been increased to €130 million and investment in Traveller-specific accommodation will rise to €34 million in 2026.

Delivering Homes, Building Communities is not a single programme or a single policy. It is a national effort that is long term, collaborative and ambitious. It is built on record investment, on evidence, and on the belief that every person in this country deserves the security of a place to call home. We do not underestimate the scale of the challenge ahead but in Delivering Homes, Building Communities we have a clear plan, the resources to deliver it and a shared determination to succeed. I look forward to our discussion today. I thank the Cathaoirleach.

I thank the Minister. We will now go to the members for questions. I remind them that the time allotted is for questions and answers so I ask them to be specific. Time slots will last seven minutes. I call Deputy Séamus McGrath.

I thank the Minister and his team for being here. The housing plan is comprehensive and I welcome it. The action plan has a significant number of different actions across a number of areas. The Minister said in his opening statement that activating supply is one of the key pillars. That is undoubtedly a critical part of trying to turn a corner on housing.

I wish to ask about the additional funding of €2.5 billion for the LDA. What is the Minister's vision for the LDA, going forward, in terms of its role and remit? We have seen an expanded role recently, which is important. I will take the opportunity to ask the Minister to outline his overall vision for the LDA.

I thank the Deputy. Activating housing is a key priority. The LDA is a key delivery partner for the Department in delivering the homes that we need across the country. We have expanded its remit across the country, and I thank my Government colleagues for the agreement to do that. The total funding now available is €8.75 billion. An additional €2.5 billion in funding will be provided to the LDA in the form of equity investment. This is in addition to the current provision of €3.75 billion in equity investment, €1.25 billion in borrowing and €1.25 billion that can be raised by the LDA through the performance of certain functions under the LDA Act or arrangements referred to in the Affordable Housing Act 2021, as provided for in the Act of 2024.

The LDA is currently updating its five-year business plan to reflect an increase in ambition, its increased remit and the additional funding that has been provided. The plan will, I have been assured, be provided to me in the first quarter of 2026 and will outline delivery to 2030. In addition to the more than 2,000 homes that the LDA has already delivered, it is working on a pipeline of a further 27,000. The LDA is now active on 40 sites with a series of projects at early stage design, planning or construction. We expect in the next couple of years for it to become the largest home delivery company, if you like, or body in the country.
That is very welcome. The LDA has shown itself to be active and successful in what it has done so far. To see an expanded role is welcome.

Another theme of the plan, and one in which the Minister strongly believes, is addressing the issue of vacant properties. There is also the under-occupation of properties and we must try to secure greater numbers of accommodation units by bringing vacant units back and increasing the occupation. Will the Minister talk about the dereliction tax that is due to come in and provide a broad timeline for it? I would also like to hear about the reform of the refurbishment grant, which I know was flagged in the plan. I also ask about the above-the-shop-type grant, which is part of the Minister's plan. On the theme of vacancy and trying to improve our overall occupation of the existing stock of buildings, perhaps the Minister will comment on how we see that unfolding in the next period.

I thank the Deputy. The best homes we can deliver are those that exist and are vacant because they do not need any additional services. We must make the best use that we can of those properties and get them back into use. That is important. It is why there are so many measures to tackle vacancy and dereliction. As I have said previously, dereliction is effectively antisocial behaviour. We are looking at different ways to tackle dereliction across the country.

The derelict property tax was announced in budget 2026. It will replace the derelict sites levy, which is currently under the remit of the local authorities. It is subject to the necessary legislation being introduced in the finance Bill 2026. Preliminary registers will be published by local authorities in 2027 and following this, there will be time for property owners to appeal the fact that their properties, or whatever the case may be, are on the register.

Using the Revenue Commissioners to target derelict properties is the way to go. Not too many countries have the approach to dereliction we do and the penalties we have. We do have challenges in terms of the application of our current dereliction law. Using the influence and power of the Revenue Commissioners is the appropriate way to do this.

Trying to reduce homelessness and provide people with long-term secure homes is a key part of the plan. There is a particular focus on child and family homelessness and trying to address that issue in the plan. Will the Minister outline how he envisages the roll-out of that with the local authorities, approved housing bodies and the various sectoral bodies helping in the homeless situation?

Tackling homelessness is a central part of the plan. That is why it is in there and forms part of the title. We are addressing homelessness in a number of different ways. The key to solving homelessness in and of itself is the sufficient supply of the homes we need in the country to tackle it. Until we get the supply up to meeting demand we have taken a number of decisions. The plan reaffirms the commitment to the Lisbon declaration in working toward the end of homelessness. We have the national homeless action plan, which in turn is helping us to develop our national homeless prevention framework. We have also secured €100 million for next year in addition to the €50 million this year, specifically to remove and exit families longest on the emergency accommodation list. We are working with every local authority as we develop our child and family homelessness action plan as well. Today I met Cork City Council. I am meeting with every local authority to ensure that not only are we making the correct decisions to tackle homelessness in this country, but that through our local authorities, which are our housing authorities, that everything is being done in each local authority to tackle homelessness. It is also to learn from them and their experience to ensure the policies we are implementing are working for the local authorities in the best way possible.

Before addressing the plan I put on record my strong objection to the manner in which the Minister is railroading through significant changes to building control legislation in the Oireachtas tomorrow. These are controversial proposals. The so-called regularisation procedure in particular will have received no scrutiny whatsoever in its legislative form. It will receive no meaningful scrutiny tomorrow. It is a retrograde step. I urge the Minister, and I will do the same tomorrow, to withdraw those amendments and utilise the proper committee procedures. We have a growing number of cases where developers are commencing developments with no commencement or other forms of certification and creating a loophole by which they will effectively be able to retrospectively secure building compliance. It is fraught with difficulties. I am not saying it is impossible, but it should not be done in the manner in which the Minister is doing it. I urge to him to reconsider.
Pre-legislative scrutiny was done on this in April 2024.

It was, and many of these concerns were raised then. However, the Minister has now produced legislation for which there will be no Oireachtas grouping. He does not understand the seriousness of what is being proposed. Therefore, while today is about the plan-----

Today's meeting is about the housing plan that was announced. I received correspondence from Deputy Ó Broin and spoke to the Minister and his officials who said they are happy to do a briefing that we will arrange for the private session tomorrow morning.

My objection still stands, although I will attend the briefing tomorrow. I turn to the plan. At the centre of the Minister's proposals to try to increase supply is a proposition about apartments. He has reduced apartment design standards to allow higher densities, smaller and darker developments. He will allow developers to reset rent to full market rent between tenancies and remove controls completely from the apartment developments. He will spend €640 million on a VAT tax break, with no benefit to supply, between 2026 and 2027.

The Society of Chartered Surveyors Ireland report today blows a huge hole into the centre of his plan. While the society has welcomed some so-called viability measures, what is striking about this report is the increasing all-in development costs for apartments. Page 17 has the full detail. Reading through that and the analysis of the implications of those costs for affordability for private rental, private purchase or cost rental it shows that the Government is not going to be able to deliver anything close to affordability, even in cost-rental schemes, with these all-in development costs, even with the huge level of subsidies it is throwing in.

Is the Minister concerned by the significant increases in all-in development costs in today's report? Is he concerned that in the vast majority of cases people would need a gross income of between €124,000 and €146,000 to be able to buy these homes? The rents that would be charged for the equivalent development costs would exclude 80% of working people and are going to have a significant upward pressure on cost rents. Does the Minister accept that there is now a problem that he did not fully anticipate in his plan? Is he going to reconsider his measures in light of today's report?
The Deputy raised several issues. Apartment specifications are being brought back in line with what would be standard across the European Union. We have a large-----
The FOI from his Department disputes that but we can discuss that separately.
-----number of apartments with planning permission that are not being built because of a viability issue. Part of that is the costs.
We know all of that. I am asking him to respond-----
The Deputy raised it as an issue, and I am addressing it.
I did, but the question time is mine and I get to decide the questions. I am specifically asking the Minister to respond as to whether he has concerns about-----
The question is in the context of his entire statement.
-----the price of the all-in development of these apartments.
One at a time, please. The Deputy asked his question but please give the Minister time to answer.
The apartment specifications are more in line with Europe because we have to get them built. The perfect apartments-----
Who is going to buy them at the prices that are detailed in the report?
No one is going to buy any apartment that is not built.
Who is going to buy an apartment costing €650,000?
My entire plan-----
Deputies, please.
The LDA will not be able to buy them.
-----is all about-----
Approved housing bodies will not be able to buy them.
Please, Deputy.
-----the delivery of supply. The entire housing plan of this Government is about increasing supply. It is also about addressing the affordability-----
How can supply be increased when the prices of the units are so high there will be no buyers?
-----and that is the challenge.

No public or private buyers. Is the Minister not genuinely concerned by the rising prices contained in today's report, and the fact that means there will not actually be a market for apartments given their cost?

I am conscious of the cost of delivering apartments and houses in this country. That is why we have taken significant viability measures. One of those was bringing specifications back in line with standards across the European Union. That is because we had standards that were too high and ensuring a situation where they were simply not being built.

Has the Minister even read the report today? Even with those changes to design standards, croí cónaithe cities, STAR and the VAT reduction, we are still talking about all-in development costs of between €500,000 and €650,000. Who is going to buy them?
We have taken significant measures to address the costs of delivery of housing in this country.
Yet the costs continue to go up.
We have also taken significant measures towards addressing the issue of affordability for people to be able to buy those homes, many of which the Deputy completely opposes.
I have not opposed any housing scheme anywhere.
Is the Deputy not opposing the first home or help to buy schemes?
What I do not understand-----
Is he in favour of them now?

The vast majority of these apartments will not be eligible for either the first home or the help to buy scheme because of the prices. That is in today's report. My question is the same. Who is going to be able to afford to buy these? Individual buyers will not be able, individual renters will not be and State agencies will not be. Who is going to buy them at the prices detailed in today's report?
We have taken significant measures to address both supply and affordability. That is what-----
They are all detailed in the report and the costs are still too high. Does the Minister understand the challenge here?
I am very much aware of the challenging situation. That is why we have published a housing plan to address those.
Is the Minister going to revise that plan in light of today's new information? It is information he clearly did not have when he produced that plan.
We take into consideration any reports published by any bodies, but we also do not take any report as gospel.

I am pretty sure the Deputy is not accepting everything in that report either, just as he waves the Housing Commission report around every day in the Dáil when he knows full well there are numerous measures in there that he does not accept. We take into consideration any report-----
Is the Minister saying this report is wrong, that the prices are lower than what is detailed here?

We take into consideration any report, Deputy, but we also do not blindly accept any report either. We have taken significant measures in the housing plan to address both viability and affordability. We need to get apartments and houses built, and we need people to be able to afford them. That is what we are doing.

I thank the Minister for his opening statement. Housing remains the defining social and economic challenge of our time, which is why I believe that the Government's new plan, Delivering Homes, Building Communities, will speed up delivery and make more homes available for our young people, who are finding it very hard to get accommodation, which we are all well aware of. Accommodation for young people is vital and important.

Community land trusts are an internationally accepted mechanism that can deliver permanent affordable housing and prevent local displacement, which is sometimes extremely relevant to my own county of Clare, with high levels of tourist demand for second and holiday homes. Unfortunately, that is not helping young people to get on the housing ladder.

Community land trusts are mentioned in section 6 of the Affordable Housing Act 2021. Housing authorities can be supported in providing affordable housing, as can community-led housing organisations and housing co-operatives. None of these options is included in the Delivering Homes, Building Communities strategy. Will the Minister commit to reviewing this oversight and consider supporting the potential of community land trusts to deliver permanent affordable houses for communities through the provision of publicly owned land?

Delivering homes in rural Ireland forms a crucial part of the housing plan, whether that is in our towns or villages, on islands or in the Gaeltacht. There are numerous measures within the plan to address that, for example, our measures around vacancy derelictions and measures with Uisce Éireann to be able to get small developers to develop in rural Ireland using the general binding guidelines with the Environmental Protection Agency, EPA, and Uisce Éireann, in addition to working towards serviced sites, particularly in villages.

As regards community land trusts, there is a pilot project in Cork. I have no particular objections and I am happy to work with the Deputy to see how we can develop policies. At present, it is certainly at a small scale but I am very happy to work with Deputy Cooney or have my officials meet him to see how we can look at expanding the possibilities there.
Does the Minister think this would deliver housing in rural parts? Does he think it would be a good idea to look at the land trusts? Would he look at the idea?
It is very much something we could look at. I want to see more detail around it but it has potential. As I said, I am very happy to engage with the Deputy's idea on this.
I thank the Minister.

Another issue is that of mixed-use single door properties. As we know, these were once the lifeblood of our towns and villages all over the country. Unfortunately, many of them are now vacant and heading into dereliction. The regeneration action under pillar 1 of the Delivering Homes, Building Communities strategy is important. The local authority purchase and renovation loan should be an obvious funding mechanism to support that. However, I have been told that single door mixed-use properties cannot be included under this scheme, which is very disappointing for rural villages and towns. We should not be closing any door that would support their reuse, which is very important, especially with the crisis we are currently in. Will the Minister commit to giving local authorities the ability to include these types of property in the local authority purchase and renovation loan scheme, even on a case-by-case pilot basis to begin with? I know from a parliamentary reply that, under the scheme, little or no use was made of the scheme between quarter 4 of 2024 and the end of quarter 2 of 2025. There were only three applications and one payout in that length of time. Something is obviously not working and it should be looked at. Does the Minister think a review of the scheme should be undertaken?

I thank Deputy Cooney for his question on the local authority property and renovation loan. It has not been used to the extent we had envisaged and perhaps we need to look at the restrictions around it to see how it can be used more effectively and more efficiently across the country. There certainly have been challenges in terms of its uptake and use. Maybe part of that is around the knowledge of it, but also how it is set up. Perhaps it is simply too restrictive. It is something I want to see an awful lot more use of and the Deputy's idea relating to mixed-use single door properties is a very good one. I do not see any reason for a restriction on that but I need to investigate it a little more. I am happy to engage with the Deputy on this.

If there was more use made of it, we would bring back more of those derelict houses throughout rural parts of the country in particular. We are all aware of town centres with small shops that no longer exist. Many of them closed down, unfortunately, and it is important that they are renovated back into residential properties. Whatever opportunity can be given to the owners of those premises should be given. I am disappointed that there is very little take up on this. The whole thing needs to be reviewed.

I agree with Deputy Cooney. The scheme needs to be looked at again to ensure it is effective. In our rural villages and towns, there are many vacant shops that are highly unlikely to come back into retail again. Using those mixed-use properties for accommodation is essential.
I thank the Minister.

The Minister claims the new housing plan increases protections for renters from evictions, but there are thousands of renters who have paid their rent and done nothing wrong and who are being evicted right now across the country. One contacted me on Sunday. She is a solicitor and is about to be made homeless. She has been renting for six years and has always paid her rent on time. She is being evicted but cannot find anywhere to rent that is below €2,500 per month. She does not know what she is going to do. What does the Minister think she should do?

Is it not true that tens of thousands who are being evicted right now, and those in existing tenancies, will receive no additional protections for tenant security from eviction after 1 March of next year? Why will the Minister not implement a temporary three-year eviction ban, like was done during Covid, to keep people in their homes?

I thank the Deputy for that. The new plan around rental properties will increase security of tenure. For the first time ever, we will have fixed security of tenure in this country, as is normal across the rest of Europe. It is the correct thing to do and is why we are bringing it in. That is not the case at present. Existing tenancies will continue under the existing rules because that is the basis in which that tenancy, both from the tenant's perspective and the landlord's perspective, entered into it. For example, the resetting rules will not apply to existing tenancies. The continued protections and situation that currently exist will continue as they are.

As regards bringing in an eviction ban, it would supply. The Deputy's focus seems to be on being populist to protect everyone who is in a rental situation right now. I do not have that luxury. I have to deliver more property so we can support renters, not just existing renters, but also those living at home who need somewhere to live. That means driving supply. An eviction ban will not do anything to drive supply; it will kill supply. Nobody is going to deliver additional properties into this State where there is an eviction ban in place. We know that from international research. The Housing Agency has done research on this. The existing rent pressure zones are killing supply. That has been the experience across the world. The research has been done on this and that is why we are bringing balanced changes. These are changes to rent pressure zones whereby we are moving to a national rent pressure zone and security of tenure under the new system for tenants while also allowing a resetting, which gives that balance. A resetting can at most be to what the market is. We have massively increased - by 70% - the funding to the Residential Tenancies Board to ensure it has the necessary ability to protect tenants as well.

That is very unfair and it is wrong to say that I am being populist in what I am saying. I am saying it because this is an ongoing humanitarian crisis. I know the Minister is aware of it and I think and hope he wants to do something more. This is an emergency and I believe that eviction ban is in place.

I will move on. As a result of the failure of numerous housing plans, we have over 500,000 people stuck in their parental homes, infantilised. What is in the plan to address this? Will the Minister also comment on the housing video, promoted by his Department, that advises young people dealing with the transition back to home? It has caused huge hurt and frustration to the hundreds of thousands who are locked at home in a form of hidden homelessness. Was the Minister aware that video was shared by the Department? Does he agree it should have been shared by the Department? Does he accept it has caused huge hurt for these people and is tone deaf for the hundreds of thousands who are struggling right now with the housing disaster?

The people who are at home are the very people for whom I am trying to activate the market so we can get more homes delivered for purchase, including more apartments for purchase and rent. Increasing supply is the only way those people are going to get out of those bedrooms and into somewhere they can live independently, safely and securely.

In respect of the video, it was prepared by SpunOut, an excellent NGO. I dealt with it when I was my party’s spokesperson on mental health. It does an awful lot of great work. It was prepared and put out by young people to talk to young people. The Department of housing did not have an involvement in it, but it retweeted it. I acknowledge the good work done by those young people and why they are doing it. We are in a housing crisis. We have a serious homelessness situation that I wish to bring to an end. I am not going to knock those young people or SpunOut for doing that.

This is not about the young people. In the context of how it feels for those people affected, does the Minister not think this is a let-them-eat-cake moment for his Department to share and promote such a video when the Department and Government are standing over, contributing to, dealing with and responding to this situation? I have received messages from people who are living the housing crisis and what they are saying to me is that this feels completely tone deaf. Whatever about this coming from SpunOut, in respect of the Department of housing, it feels to those people that the Minister is saying this is what they should do in terms of the housing crisis. I understand some of the stuff in the video with regard to helping people through transition and change, but in the context of the housing crisis and what is going on, it has really upset people.

I read the Deputy's comments. I must have missed the part where he acknowledged it was SpunOut and young people who did it. Instead, he seems to be obsessed with somehow putting the blame for it on me. My Department and I did not lead this. We did not have any involvement in it.
It is my understanding that the Housing Agency commissioned it.

I was not aware of it. An official in the Department of housing, well-intentioned but maybe misconceived, saw what young people in SpunOut were doing and reposted it. There is nothing sinister about it.
It is not about being sinister; it is about-----
There is no conspiracy behind it.
-----the frustration. As the Minister said, it was misconceived for the Department to promote that video.

It was misconceived. A bit of balance is needed here. These are young people in SpunOut, who did fantastic work. They deserve credit for their work and what they were doing to try to help other young people. The Department had no role in the video but it reposted it. Reposting the video was misconceived but there is an attempt to try to paint a picture – I read comments in the national media to this effect – that somehow this was directed by me, the Department or whatever the case may be. I am conscious of the pressure young people are under living at home. I want to get them homes. While I hear what I am doing constantly being knocked, I am not hearing alternatives. My aim is to get those young people-----
That is not true either. We put alternatives to the Minister, like the State savings scheme, and he ignored it.
-----out of those homes and into homes. We did not ignore it.
It is not in the housing plan.
There is a difference between not ignoring something and doing something.
There is a difference between saying we are not putting forward any solutions when we have put forward some.

All my focus is on finding homes for those young people at home. I am conscious of the stress those young people are under. As I said, everything I do every day is to try to deliver the homes for those young people to have somewhere to live safely and securely.
Susanne is in my office in Dún Laoghaire at the moment. She is facing eviction with her two children with special needs by Park Development, one of the biggest builders in the country.
I ask the Deputy to be careful about naming a development company.
Why?
I am just making the point.

This is not some mom-and-pop landlord, as the Minister often refers to, evicting someone. Rather, this is a business that makes money out of a housing situation in this country. Susanne wants to know what she is supposed to do. Park Development is refusing to sell to the council because it wants to get the highest price it can get. It just wants to profit out of the fact that it is going to make her and several others who are facing a similar situation in the Glencairn View estate, which is just off the N11, homeless. This is because the Minister has turned his face, and has repeated it here today, against having a no-fault eviction ban for people who have done nothing wrong and children with special needs. In the Minister’s document, it says there will be a framework to deal with the prevention of homelessness. How does it fit in with Susanne? Tell me because the plan is vague. It mentions engaging with local authorities and having a framework. How is the framework going to help Susanne and her kids and other people who are facing eviction through no fault of their own?
As I said, my view is that an eviction ban will kill the supply of additional homes in this country for everyone who needs those homes, not just those who are currently renting.
Okay, the Minister has said that. What should be done for Susanne and her kids?
I am not going to talk about an individual person.
For anyone in her situation.
For anyone in her situation, we are bringing out the homelessness prevention framework. What we do-----
A framework.
Where someone is coming into a homeless situation-----
Will it help Susanne stay out of homelessness?

-----if they cannot find an alternative place to live, what happens is the local authority, and the HAP people working within the local authority, try to help to find an alternative place to live. We are also-----

She has been offered a HAP payment of €1,700. She is looking for a three-bedroom home. Try and find a rental property anywhere in south Dublin, or anywhere in Dublin, on a HAP limit of €1,700. You can forget about it. Does the Minister have any comment on the hopelessness of that situation?
Every effort is then made to help find that person somewhere to live. We are also driving social housing supply so that-----
What efforts are being made?

-----fewer people need it. We are bringing in changes in the rent pressure zones for renters. For example, if very large landlords are selling property, they cannot sell with the tenant in it. That is why we are bringing in that security of tenure. It is to ensure that someone is protected within that. We are bringing in a number of measures, both to strengthen tenants' rights and also help prevent people going into homelessness. Where it does happen-----
Can the Minister just be specific?
We are also increasing the social housing supply.

Can the Minister just be specific? He has used the word "prevention" and it is in the plan. He has mentioned “prevention” and “frameworks”. How is his prevention framework going to help Susanne and her kids?
I have explained it. Where someone is becoming homeless-----
It is not clear to me what I should tell her.
Will the Deputy please let the Minister answer? He asked a question and should let the Minister answer.
Obviously, I cannot address an individual situation, but what happens is-----
This is typical.

-----the local authority engages with that individual person. We are increasing significantly the number of social houses. One would hope that there may be a situation where that person could be offered a social house. If not, an alternative HAP can be provided. There are also homeless HAP supports as well. We are also bringing in reforms of our landlord and tenant law to ensure that it is far more difficult for someone in that situation to be evicted in the future.

Tell that to Park Development. I understood that the LDA was supposed to be offered all public land that was available for housing. Last night, councillors on Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown County Council were informed that DLR Properties Limited, a wholly owned subsidiary of Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown County Council, is selling land to private developers after a deal with Tuath Housing, an AHB, for 67 houses collapsed.

I do not know why it collapsed but, unbelievably, DLR Properties Limited, a wholly owned subsidiary of a local authority, is selling and the councillors are told that none of it is their business, there is nothing they can do and they have no input whatsoever. Apparently, DLR Properties Limited is going to get rid of loads more land - a lot of it is up in Cherrywood - that almost certainly could be used for public and affordable housing. I am asking for the Minister to intervene. That is a disgrace in the face of the crisis. With land prices as such, and with land banking and so on, the idea of a public body getting rid of land that could be used for public housing or affordable housing is a disgrace. Will the Minister intervene?
No, I would not intervene in an individual situation.
That is another one.

Land is to be offered to the LDA on a first-option basis but it is not the case that the LDA will take every single piece of public land that is available. It will engage with, for example, local authorities. The local authorities do have to decide what is the best way to deliver the most amount of homes in their area.
So it is going to be allowed to sell the land. That is absolutely disgraceful and the Minister is not going to intervene.

I think €13 million was given in local infrastructure housing activation fund, LIHAF, funding to the developers in Cherrywood - by the way, a lot of DLR Properties Limited land is up there as well - the biggest residential development in the entire country, where properties are now being sold by private developers for €600,000 and €700,000, which is clearly unaffordable. For the €13 million in LIHAF funding, we were supposed to get affordable housing. It is more than a decade on and there is no sign of any affordable housing. There is none - zero - for the money we paid for the infrastructure. How could that be the case? Could the Minister explain that, when there is supposed to be a commitment to affordable housing from this Government?
I am not familiar with the specific LIHAF situation-----
Could the Minister even look into it?
-----but I will engage with the local authority and my own officials.

In regard to people over the threshold, I raised this last week. If you are over the threshold and facing eviction, you are kind of goosed. What can the Minister say to people who are over the threshold and where there are no supports for them if they are facing homelessness because they are over the social housing threshold?

For older people who might be trying to access affordable housing, particularly those who face an eviction, any affordable schemes the Department has are pretty much closed off to them because they are too old. They will not pass muster for getting loans, even the local authority home loan, because they are too close to the end of their working lives. Is there anything the Minister can say to help them?

My understanding is that the first question is in relation to somebody who is maybe above the social housing threshold but below the cost rental. Is that what the Deputy is saying? They are falling between the gap there.
Yes.

I will always keep these under review and I am happy to hear any examples from the Deputy but my aim is always to ensure that on that spectrum, somebody falls in somewhere in order that if people are on the affordable housing spectrum, if it is not cost rental, there is another affordable measure there for them if they are above the social housing. It is something I keep constantly under review and I am very anxious to hear of any examples where people are falling between the different schemes - because I want to be sure there are no gaps between them - or if somebody has a solution, whatever that solution may be.

In relation to older people, older people who have been renting their entire lives and now find themselves in a situation where they are struggling to get a housing solution is becoming an increasing problem. I acknowledge that with the Deputy. It is a situation that the Minister of State, Deputy Kieran O'Donnell, is working on to try and come up with what measures we need to address that. I think we probably need new measures to address that particular situation, which concerns a growing cohort. It is a very frightening position for those people to be in and I certainly acknowledge that.

I wish to turn to the plan in relation to starter homes and the intention to deliver 15,000 starter homes per annum. I know the Minister has listened to me on occasions in regard to affordable purchase. It is critically important that this is a core part of the starter home package, in my view. Specifically, what are the key actions to try to ramp up the delivery of affordable purchase across the State, the local authorities and other suppliers and through the Part V provision as well? It is a critical part of the starter home package and we really need to see delivery of higher numbers of affordable purchase. I ask the Minister to comment on that please.

I thank the Deputy and I agree. On the starter homes, affordable purchase is a key element of that. We have significant funding to be able to help deliver affordable purchase. Some local authorities are now delivering a significant amount. Some local authorities seem to be a little bit reluctant to move on affordable purchase. That may be the case because some local authorities probably feel a little bit burned from past experiences as well. We are working with those specific local authorities to find a pathway to maximise delivery of affordable purchase as a housing solution for those who want to avail of it.
I thank the Minister. He knows my views on it. It is a critical part of the starter home package so I would ask that every effort is made to work with the local authorities to ramp up supply.

I will turn to something that was touched on by some of the speakers so far. I refer to the limits with regard to the first home scheme, the help-to-buy scheme and the local authority home loan. I have raised this issue with the Minister in the Dáil as well. There are many first-time buyers who find themselves outside those limits. The help-to-buy scheme has a €500,000 ceiling with regard to the price of the property. The first home scheme, in relation to Cork, for example, is €450,000 in the county and so on. Many first-time buyers are simply outside that in regard to the properties available to them to purchase. Similarly, in regard to the local authority home loan, I was contacted recently by someone who has gone through a separation and hopes to avail of the fresh start principle under that but, again, the limit that is on the first home scheme is presenting a problem.
Overall, I know the Minister said they are constantly under review. Can we take some optimism that there will be a look at these limits in the very near future?

Very much so. I appreciate that there are certain areas in this country where the limits, especially near border areas of different local authorities, can have a bit of a negative impact in terms of the supports that are needed, especially where, perhaps on those border areas, prices can be quite similar but the amount of supports can differ as a result of one local authority being considerably lower. It can be. These limits are kept under review. Most of them are kept under independent review. We want to ensure that we maximise the supports people can get without driving inflation or driving up the overall housing cost. I assure the Deputy that all of these schemes are currently under review with a view to ensuring the right balance of supports are there without creating any unintended consequences or driving up the overall price of housing.

Continuing on the theme of limits and the income limits for social housing, they are quite restrictive at the moment. There is quite a low income limit. I know it varies across the country but the Minister mentioned earlier about closing gaps between individual families who qualify for social housing, and the next step with regard to cost rental, affordable purchase or whatever may be available. It is quite a significant gap at present and part of the solution has to be narrowing that gap through the increase of the social housing income limits. Is it intended that we will look at those income limits in the near future?

Absolutely. I am looking at those limits. The last time they increased was 2023 and we are now coming into 2026. There has been inflation in that period as well, which will have affected people's ability, that balance and the spectrum where people's certain income limits would come into. We are reviewing all of those at the moment. The first home scheme price thresholds, for example, are being actively reviewed at the moment but I am looking at the social housing thresholds as well to ensure everybody falls within the correct or most suitable housing solution to meet their needs. It increased by €5,000 in 2023 but I am conscious there has been significant inflation since that time.

I would appreciate if the Minister could look at that as soon as possible. In relation to rightsizing, it is in the plan and it is very important. Whenever we talk about rightsizing or downsizing, it is always important to reiterate that it is totally voluntary and up to the individuals in regard to freeing up a family home, if it is something they want to do, but the options have to be there for them. What I am hearing from elderly people is that they do not see the options out there.

They would vacate their traditional family home but they do not see a place for them to go - somewhere that is attractive to them, that is secure and that is designed appropriately in terms of a single-storey property. The Minister mentioned it in the plan in terms of rightsizing. Some local authorities have embraced it quite well while others have not. What can we do to ensure local authorities embrace it across the country? Some local authorities simply do not have a rightsizing scheme. The scheme needs to be looked at in terms of reform but it also needs to be rolled out across the country and our 31 local authorities. I welcome it in the plan. How can we make it a reality and deliver on it?

I know a number of local authorities have run these types of schemes, including Limerick and Cork. There is no national scheme to help people rightsize. The Minister of State, Deputy O'Donnell, is working on an plan for older persons of which rightsizing is a key part. Where people want to rightsize, two things very much hold them back. One is bridging finance, while the other is getting a property in their local area. They want to stay in their communities and be close to their families and what they are familiar with. It is about ensuring that staying within the local community is an option for older people, in particular if they want to rightsize. If they want to stay in their existing home, they should be helped to do that as well. It is about what works for them. I find that many older people are willing to rightsize but only where the alternative accommodation meets their needs.

I totally agree. Regarding the focus on homelessness, on child and family homelessness and the need to acquire larger properties, the rightsizing scheme has the potential to deliver larger properties. There are many four-bedroom properties that people would willingly give up if they feel there is somewhere attractive for them to go. It can certainly help address family homelessness. There are many benefits to a rightsizing scheme and it is important that it is rolled out across the country.
Our public session next week focuses on homelessness.

I thank the Minister and his officials for being here. The new plan commits to developing a new voids programme. What will this look like? When will it be in place? Will it bridge the funding gap that is there?

We are looking at a voids programme. We already provide very significant money for voids - €260 million for local authorities in 2026. It is and remains the duty of local authorities to ensure their stock is maintained-----

I do not mean to interrupt the Minister but I am asking specifically about the new plan. I am not talking about local authorities. The new plan commits to developing a new voids programme. What will this look like?

A key part of it is that principle that local authorities are responsible for ensuring that voids, which are vacant social housing, are turned over as quickly as possible and are maintained. I have already said that from next year alone, €216 million will be-----
To clarify, we are talking about the new plan. Maybe there is another plan that exists that I do not know about for local authorities. I am talking about the Minister's plan.
That is what I am talking about.
There is nothing specific in it. We are passing the buck to local authorities. Is there anything in the plan? Is there any funding in it? What will it look like?
Local authorities maintaining their own stock is not passing the buck.
We are back to local authorities. I am asking the Minister a straightforward question. We are here to discuss-----
Voids are local authority properties. The Deputy is asking me to talk about a plan about voids without mentioning local authorities.
Deputy Gould should give the Minister time to answer the question.
We are not here to talk about local authorities. We are here to talk about-----
Voids.

-----the plan. We are here to talk about the plan. There is no additional funding. I asked the Minister last week or the week before in this committee whether there was any additional funding for local authorities to return voids and he said "No". I thanked him for his honesty. We could clear long-term family homelessness in this State by returning the voids programmes. The Minister is putting that on the local authorities. I asked him what is in the plan to specifically solve that. There are two families in Cork who have been over four years on the list, three families who are over three years on the list, 25 families who are over two years on the list and 73 families who have been on the list for over a year. There are hundreds of boarded-up houses in Cork. Cork City Council had to put up rates this year because it did not have the money. The Minister is saying that local authorities have to do it. Cork City Council had to put up rates on businesses that are struggling and barely hanging on to balance a budget. It also had to put up the local property tax to balance the budget. Where is Cork City Council getting that money? It put up rates and the local property tax. What else is it supposed to put up? It looks like the Minister wants all local authorities to put up rents. That is the only way they can raise their income.

We will move on. The Minister's plan commits to 15,000 affordable homes on average. Last year, 7,100 were delivered. The Minister is not delivering on targets for social, affordable and cost rental. We need those targets to be able to monitor how this plan is going. Will he deliver those targets?

Local authorities will have targets. The target for social housing for next year is 10,200. We are continuing to work with local authorities in terms of their targets to maximise the delivery of social and affordable homes. Our local authorities, which are our housing authorities, are critical to delivering an awful lot of the housing solutions.
I understand that but what are the targets for social, affordable and cost rental for next year?
For 2026, the target for social housing is 10,200.
What about affordable housing?

For starter homes, we are looking on average to hit 15,000 units. We have a very good chance of achieving that. I do not have the figure for cost rental in front of me but I can get it for the Deputy.

I would like that because those figures should be in every plan. I must have contacted the Minister's office a half a dozen times if not more looking for data on derelict sites. Normally derelict site figures are produced in the first quarter of every year. It is now December and I still do not have access to them. I have raised this a number of times with the Minister. Are derelict site figures being withheld by the Minister, his Department or someone because every year I have been a TD, I have been able to get those figures at the start of the year or after the first quarter? Here we are in December and we do not have access to them. Why are figures relating to the derelict sites register, levies and the performance of local authorities being withheld? Will the Minister commit to releasing them after today?
They are not being withheld. We are dependent on local authorities for that information and are working with them to finalise the figures so the figures will be released.

How come it is nine months later? I sent an FOI to every local authority over the summer and again last month. I can get the information. I am a backbench TD from an Opposition party and I can get the information. Deputy Browne is the Minister with a Department. Is he telling me that local authorities are withholding information they are obliged to give him and his Department? I find that hard to believe.
All I can tell the Deputy is that we are finalising those figures and they will be published.
When will they be published? Will they be published before Christmas?
I do not have the exact date in front of me.
Can the Minister understand my frustration? These are published at the start of every year. We want to be constructive. We want this plan to work.

I swear to God we want this plan to work. I held a clinic yesterday. I got out of that clinic at 3 o'clock. We were in there the whole day dealing with people. Housing is the number one issue, as is the number of people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. We want the plan and we want to be constructive. The Minister's document states that he is committed to the plan of ending homelessness by 2030. The Minister's plan states that we affirm our commitment to the Lisbon declaration "to work towards ending homelessness by 2030" on page 60. At the current rate, there is no way the Government will do that, in this plan that has been outlined. I will ask the Minister a question that I asked his predecessor, the Taoiseach and the Tánaiste. If the Government does not end homelessness by 2030, will the Minister accept that it is a failure of his as the housing Minister?
We need to move on now.
I would like an answer, Chair.
I deal with issues as they arise. I have my plan and will speak to it.
It is contained in the Minister's document.
Deputy Aird, who is standing in for Deputy Butterly, is next.

I have a question for the Minister. I have been in contact with the Minister to ask him about a girl with disabilities. April is the girl's name and I have been working with her for many years. She would now be described as a mature student. She spent a lot of time during her life having operations. She eventually qualified and was on the housing list of Laois County Council. As she has taken up a job for herself, she now finds that she is above the threshold and the council has informed me that she will have to be taken off the housing list. We have social houses that will soon be completed by Laois County Council and one of them that is being built would have been suitable for her needs. This is very wrong. I have spoken to the Minister and his officials. I came to the committee meeting today to see if I could prolong the date because he kept telling me that Laois County Council sets the thresholds. Laois County Council does not set the threshold. The threshold is set for the council by the Minister's Department and the council abides by the rules of that. Surely there is some concession for a person who is confined with disabilities. If this person was on HAP, the income from the little job she got would not have affected her. She could never get HAP because she could never get accommodation to rent suitable for her needs. That is point number one. Number two is that she can never, ever get a loan because she cannot get mortgage protection. Surely there has to be some compassion here.

I remind members that the discussion today is on the housing plan in general. I ask them to be careful about discussing the specifics of any person. I do not think this is the place to talk about that matter. Maybe the Minister and his officials will talk to Deputy Aird off-site.

I have already spoken to them and cannot get a result. I am sorry, but it is Christmas time and I am very downbeat over this. It has been going on for a good few years. It was going to be a happy Christmas for this girl. It is a simple thing. There has to be some leeway for people with disabilities. There is no leeway - not a fivepenny piece of leeway - and I think it is so wrong. We cannot compare people with disabilities with any other person who is on the list because those people can go out, seek and get accommodation but this girl could not get accommodation. She could not avail of the HAP because there was no suitable accommodation to be got. There is no accommodation that is suitable to her needs. Laois County Council was going to provide the accommodation suitable to her needs.
I remind the Deputy that today's discussion is about the housing plan in general and not specific cases
This is part of the housing plan. I am not on this committee. I came in because I asked if I could have the time.
I let the Deputy in.

I know. I did the same thing already today. I chaired the agriculture committee this morning and I let two people in because other people did not come. I am just asking the question. If I cannot get answers at an Oireachtas committee meeting like this, where will I get the answers? I spent an hour yesterday at Laois County Council on this particular subject. I have been at it for years and it is so close to my heart. I am very passionate about it because I think it is wrong. That is all.

The Deputy is very passionate about this situation and case. I can get one of the senior officials, such as the Secretary General, to talk to the Deputy to see if there is some way of resolving this particular situation. To be fair to the Deputy, he has been raising this issue for a few weeks now or longer.
I thank the Minister.
I thank the Minister. I had another question about what he was doing but I will not put them.
The Deputy still has another three minutes.
No, it is all right. I will give it to the other members. I thank the members of the housing committee for allowing me in. That is all.
Sorry, the Deputy came in. He has three minutes left for other questions. He is taking Deputy Butterly's slot.

I will give it to the other members who are here. That is all other than to say I was a member of the council for many years. There is a need for joined-up thinking when a local authority makes a submission to the Department of housing saying it is ready to go for planning for more houses. It is taking up to ten years from the time a site - a piece of land - is purchased to the time somebody, whoever it is, cuts the ribbon. That is what I have seen down through the years. It is now worse instead of better. In 1992 Laois County Council bought 8 acres of land and in 1995 - three years later - the 8 acres of land was completely built out. That would not happen now. It would take ten or 12 years before it would happen. I would just like to say-----
I ask the Deputy to let the Minister answer that. Changes have been made during the past 12 months.
Laois County Council, as the Minister knows, is the best council in the country for delivering housing. We are the very best in the country.
The Minister to respond.

Thanks very much Cathaoirleach. The Deputy is right when he says that it is a very good local authority. During the last year, we have abolished the four-stage process and moved to a single-stage one. We have increased the limits under which the local authority can deliver homes from €17 million to €200 million, giving them a huge increased scope. We have issued standardised manual design to make it more straightforward for local authorities to know what needs to be designed and built and how to deliver housing. As these changes wash into the system, I think we will see local authorities being able to move an awful lot more quickly. I want us to remove some of those constraints to assist local authorities, like Laois County Council, that have the capacity to drive on with housing delivery.
That would solve the housing problem.

I thank Deputy Aird. I omitted to mention at the beginning there were apologies from Deputy Paul McAuliffe and Senator Pat Casey. The next slot falls to Fianna Fáil again. I think I will let Deputy Ó Broin in as a second speaker rather than having three, to be fair. Deputy Ó Broin is to come back in. I think Senator McCormack is voting in the Seanad.
She is voting in the Seanad.
Senator Anne Rabbitte is voting as well.
Will the Minister tell us when he is going to publish the social, affordable, purchase and cost-rental delivery figures for quarter 3? Will it be before the Dáil breaks for Christmas?
The aim is to try to do that but I cannot guarantee it. That is certainly the aim.
Is the Minister in any position to give us any indication as to whether the slow rate of progress in the first two quarters will improve in quarter 3? Has he had sight of draft figures at this stage?
I have not looked at draft figures yet but our aim is always to increase the delivery.

The Minister mentioned to my colleague that there is a cost-rental target for next year that he will share with the committee. Will he also confirm if there is an affordable purchase target for next year and share that with the committee if he does not have it with him today?
In terms of starter homes, that is a broad base.

My question is specifically about the affordable purchase scheme. Will there be a target for the affordable purchase scheme next year? The Minister told this committee at an earlier session that this year's target for affordable purchase is 2,100. Will there be a target for that scheme for next year?
I will have to get clarification on that for the Deputy.

Yes, if the Minister could share it with the committee. When he was with the committee previously he told us that the affordable purchase target for this year is 2,100 and the cost-rental target across the various agencies is 2,350. I am looking for comparable figures for next year.

One of the other issues I have raised regularly - it is even more important now - is that the affordable purchase and the cost rental schemes have not only been underperforming in terms of missing the targets and the total number, but the price of both schemes is rising. Deputy Séamus McGrath rightly raised his concerns around affordable purchase earlier. We are being told by the LDA and the approved housing bodies that there is a growing number of people who, when they apply either for cost rental or affordable purchase, are being priced out.

They earn too much to be eligible for social housing but do not earn enough to be able to access cost rental or affordable purchase. When this was raised with officials previously, we were told this was not an issue being tracked by the Department. Given that cost rental in particular is an important form of tenure for those who fall between the two stools of the private and the social, will the Minister give a commitment that the Department will start tracking the number of households excluded from those schemes solely on affordability grounds? That would give us a sense of the scale of the challenge. In some of the developments I have seen, such as cost-rental developments with the LDA or approved housing bodies, as many as 50% if not more of the applicants who would be deemed eligible on all other grounds are not eligible on the affordability grounds. Therefore, they have no options; neither social, cost rental nor the private market. Will the Minister give a commitment to start tracking that issue in the Department so we can have visibility on the size of that group which is now being excluded?
It is a group of people I am always very concerned about if they are being excluded from various schemes. I can commit to looking at whether that is viable.

To be helpful, it is. I have written to a number of AHBs asking if they can provide that data and they can. I am not sure if a couple of the smaller AHBs hold it but for the majority of the properties, the LDA, Clúid, Respond and Tuath can do so. There was a report in the Irish Daily Mail today about the doubling of the number of people in their 60s in the private rental sector. Many of those people have occupational pensions and on retirement their income will fall, they will struggle to pay private rents and also struggle to pay cost rents and may not be eligible for social housing. Will the Minister give a commitment that data will be collated and discussed with committee periodically? That would be useful.

Does the Minister have any concerns about the rising prices of the cost rental and affordable purchase schemes? We are seeing prices for two-bedroom and three-bedroom cost-rental units of €1,700 and €1,900 a month. They are 25% below market rent but they are very high rents. Likewise, the use of open market valuation for affordable purchase means the all-in price, if you want one of the units completely, is very high. Is the Department following those upward movements of price? Does the Minister have any concern about the trajectory of where they are going?

We closely follow them. Any upward trajectory impacts affordability; there is no question. We have sought to take measures to try to address that through, for example, corporation tax changes. It is something-----

Paschal Donohoe was before the finance committee and I asked him specifically about this. He said the reduction in corporation tax would not be passed on to new cost-rental tenants of the LDA in rent reductions. It was solely, as he described it, a viability measure. We had quite a detailed exchange. He said at no stage was the discussion with him around reductions in rents for new cost-rental tenants so the corporation tax exemption will not have any impact on the rents. Does the Minister accept that? He seems to be suggesting something different to the former finance Minister.
The aim is to maximise the delivery of the number of cost-rental properties made available to us.
Does the Minister accept it will not have any impact on downward pressure on rents because that is not the purpose of that measure?
We will work through it.

The former Minister for Finance was much more definitive. The Minister said he got rid of the one-stage process. That is not my understanding - work is still ongoing. Is the new one-stage process now in place and local authorities can apply for it, or are the details of the scheme still being worked out?
I have made the decision to get rid of it.
Has the Minister got rid of it? Can a local authority today apply under this new scheme or process or is it still being worked through with the local authorities?
It has been finalised with local authorities and should be fully in place-----
When does the Minister expect it will be open for people to apply?
It should be in place in the next couple of weeks.

It is the Minister's intention to publish data on its usage? There was very poor uptake, as the Minister knows, of the previous one-stage process in the number of applications in units. Does the Minister intend to publish information on that?

Absolutely. The previous one-stage process was not availed of too often. That was because the limit was so low and the local authority was responsible if it went above the limit. Understandably, local authorities were risk averse in those circumstances. Unless the delivery was very much at the bottom end, they were not prepared to take that risk.
Will the Minister forward the figures for 2026 projections for affordable houses?
It is two schemes - cost rental and affordable purchase. If that can be provided to the committee, it would be very welcome.

Will the Minister forward those figures? Deputy Gould wanted details of derelict sites for 2024 and 2025. They should be available early in the first quarter of 2026. Local authorities should forward that information. I will call Deputy Hearne because he has to go to speak in the Chamber. I will then call Deputy Séamus McGrath.

The first area I want to focus on is the issue of starter homes. Are there targets? The Minister said 15,000 but are there targets specifically for affordable purchase and cost rental? I know we have asked for the figures but has the Department set targets for each year?

Housing action plans are currently being developed. Our overall target remains 15,000 starter homes. Numbers within that will remain flexible. We have to bring flexibility into the system to maximise the use of various schemes. I am always reluctant around actual specific targets because they become an end in themselves rather than the overall purpose which is to maximise housing delivery. That is the overall mission we need to aim towards.

I was very critical of the lack of annual targets in the plan itself. I feel there in an issue in that. I know the Minister has a different view. If we are trying to get local authorities, not-for-profit housing bodies, which in particular are core, and the LDA to ramp up delivery, whatever about the overall targets - which I still think should be in the plan - does the Minister accept there should be targets for them so they know where they are aiming? I understand what the Minister said about flexibility but surely there is a need to say this is what we need to deliver if we are going to deliver sufficient affordable housing, for example.

We know what we need to deliver. Our aim is for the LDA, the AHBs and the local authorities to maximise delivery. I do not want anybody to get a sense that there is a target and when we get to that target, that is our job done. When you go back to the core principle of the mission, which is to maximise delivery, that is where I want all the focus on. The overall targets are minimum targets we want people to achieve and focus on.

On the area of affordable purchase, we had Dara Turnbull from Housing Europe at the committee. The Minister is probably aware of that organisation. He spoke about a missing sector in Ireland in housing which is co-operative housing or community-led affordable housing. I know the Housing Agency has been doing some work on that. There is no ambition or target for delivering that affordable co-operative housing-led sector in the housing plan. It is a gap. Did the Minister explore it and not want to put it in the housing plan? Will he talk about that? Has he considered it?

I am aware that it is being looked at. It is innovative in the context of Ireland. There will probably be proposals going forward. I am open to seeing how they can be used. They are not far enough advanced to form part of a plan at this stage.

The Minister, the Department and the Government should promote it more. It is a real solution in places like Copenhagen where people co-own apartment blocks as tenants and renters. They buy equity in it. We have a long history of co-operative housing development in Ireland. There is a need to promote in particular the community land trust model. I would appreciate if the Minister would look into that.

On the State savings scheme proposal we made, the Minister said in the Dáil that the Department is looking into it and we discussed it with Ms Timmons as well. It is a real opportunity. I know there is a broad acceptance that we need more funding and finance. The Taoiseach's argument is that this would take years to set up and is not really going to have a material impact now. Surely the longer you make that argument, of course it is going to go on longer. If we start now doing that model like in France, it seems an obvious one. The current models are not that.

They are not where people can go into any bank, open an account called, let us say, the State savings account, and then that money is being channelled into affordable housing or social housing. There is a real opportunity in Ireland, in particular, to funnel it towards the private affordable housing delivery market. The Minister might give an update on that.

I thank the Deputy very much. I did ask the Department of Finance. I undertook to look at the Livret A measure because it is the Department that would be leading on it. I hear the Deputy on a very specific Livret A-type measure, but the response from the Department of Finance was that its view is that the National Treasury Management Agency, NTMA, already operates the State savings schemes, which provide a range of products. The total value in the State savings schemes totalled €24.3 billion at December 24. The NTMA in turn provides a source of funds to the Housing Finance Agency, Home Building Finance Ireland, HBFI, and the LDA as well through the Ireland Strategic Investment Fund, ISIF. There are concerns that a Livret A scheme would detract from the other investment schemes. However, I will certainly ask the Department of Finance to keep it under review.
I appreciate that. I do think it is a real potential solution.

The other area is in relation to rents and student rents. It has been reported in the media that the Department of higher education wants more regular increases of rents allowed in terms of student accommodation. However, it has been reported that the Minister said he wants the situation of every six years to apply to student accommodation. Can he clarify what exactly his position is at the moment in relation to that?

Our position, as stated publicly, is that it is six years for resetting. I am not going to get into any ongoing discussions between the various Departments or what has been reported in the media and what is or is not correct. It is not what we do. The current proposal is not just the six-year resetting, but because sometimes there can be a higher turnover of students within student-specific accommodation, there would be a three-year maximum reset on it so it could only happen once. It is, therefore, an additional restriction.
Yes, because there is that turnover every year, essentially.
It is an additional restriction, if you like, on student-specific accommodation, but that is currently where we are at.
Would that apply to private student accommodation?
No, it will not apply to private student accommodation. I have been very clear on that.
Just student accommodation-----
I thank the Deputy.
I am sorry.
We are just-----
It is purpose-built student accommodation.
Both private and public if it is purpose-built.
If it is on a university. Purpose-built student accommodation has a very specific identifiable approach to it being built, so legally it can be separated out.

I will turn to the issue of finance for the construction sector. The Minister mentions in the plan additional funding of €400 million for the Ireland Strategic Investment Fund and €200 million for Home Building Finance Ireland. Will he elaborate for us what exactly he intends that funding package will help with?
Is this the equity fund for smaller builders?
Yes.

I expect to be launching that in the very near future. It is very important because we have made a number of significant measures to activate large-scale development. However, I am also very conscious that a key element of how we address our housing crisis is by maximising delivery of smaller developments and through smaller and medium-sized developers. They, in particular, have a real challenge right now. I spoke earlier about how we have tried to address one of their challenges through developer-led wastewater infrastructure and then also developing serviced sites. However, the other way is the equity piece. Small and medium-sized developers are struggling to get loans from banks because of the very high equity demand. Their alternative, in some cases, to meet that equity need is to go out and borrow on international financial markets at very high rates.
