Therefore, what we are attempting to do with the Tánaiste and Minister for Finance, Deputy Simon Harris, with the banks is to try to plug some of that equity gap at a much lower interest rate. That is where we see this fund coming into place. We would expect that fund would be used as property as built and sold. Obviously, there are repayments, and that fund can be continuously reused and replenished.
That is good because smaller builders and smaller developers have a lot to offer. Affordable finance is certainly one of the key issues for them, so the provision of that fund is very welcome.

I will go back to the issue of vacancy. It is widely viewed that there are over 100,000 vacant properties across the State. The Minister's plan has a number of key measures in relation to it. The derelict property tax is a welcome initiative as far as I am concerned. I agree with the Minister that people sitting on properties and not activating them is a major social issue. There are complex reasons in many cases but at the same time, there are others where there are not complex reasons. People are simply letting them lie. If that tax is to work, we need to significantly look at the derelict site register that is there at the moment. It is only capturing a very small number of those derelict properties as far as I am concerned. It is around 3,000 nationally if I am correct. We are looking at 3,000 captured out of a potential vacancy pool of 100,000, although they are not all derelict; I appreciate that. While we are waiting for this tax to be set up - it is taking a long time as far as I am concerned and I am sure the Minister would share my concerns there - we can do a lot to improve the current derelict sites list. We need to work closely with the local authorities to do that to try to ramp up the number of properties that are captured. Perhaps the Minister would take that away. He might comment on it today as well to see how we can dramatically improve that in terms of capturing the properties that are both derelict and vacant.

I thank the Deputy very much. In terms of local authorities, there is a fair amount of forewarning now that the derelict sites are coming in under the Revenue Commissioners. I would hope local authorities are going to continue and will add to that the number of derelict properties across the country. We will be working with the local authorities to ensure that is the case.

It is also looking at the definitions of what is derelict and what is vacant and ensuring that there is no opportunity for properties to slip in between the two. As far as I am concerned, if a person's property is not being occupied and it meets the threshold for being vacant, it is either vacant or derelict. We do need to look at the definitions again, and the Deputy has been very strong on this, and rightly so, in order that there is no opportunity for any properties to slip between the vacant or derelict definitions. It can come down to local authority interpretations, but for some of those, the derelict definition is perhaps a bit dated. We need to look at that definition as part of the reform in terms of the derelict tax that is going to come in as well.

Absolutely. As a former councillor for a good number of years, I am all for local authorities to be given discretion. At the same time, however, there has to be consistency brought to bear on this issue in terms of the definition of dereliction because as far as I can see, there is too much inconsistency across the country in relation to it. Certainly, looking at that definition is a key part of it, so I would very much welcome that.

The Minister is all for reforming the planning system through the implementation of the Planning and Development Act 2024, providing certainty, clearer timelines and better outcomes. It is very welcome. What can be achieved there? Can we achieve what we would be hoping to achieve in that? We are well aware that all planning applications are taking a long time at the moment, and it is actually putting developers off getting involved in buying land and developing it. I am well aware it is because of all the criteria and red tape they have to go through. Will this achieve the speeding up of planning applications?

Very much so, and the Minister of State, Deputy Cummins, is doing very good work in this area. We have done a number of things to speed up planning. We set up An Coimisiún Pleanála, and it is now meeting 90% of all of its statutory timelines. Anybody appealing is now getting that turnover very quickly.
In relation to the local authorities, we are working with the Minister, Deputy Lawless, in terms of increasing the number of people going into the whole area of planning.

We are also working with the Minister, Deputy Burke, and planning expertise is now included on the critical skills list. What the Minister of State, Deputy Cummins, is doing through the planning exemptions is a huge body of work that will come in in the first quarter of next year. It will clear off a huge amount of the workload from our planners in our local authorities to allow them to focus on housing delivery. They will no longer be caught up in what they spend an awful lot of their time doing now, namely, enforcing very small planning issues that really should not be needing a planning decision at all. I do not want to prejudge the outcome, but an example would be needing planning permission for a Velux window in the front of your house, for example. A bus shelter also needs planning permission, which seems a bit odd. I think there will be lots of these exemptions. This is the approach. We need more planners. It is quite difficult, however, to find skilled planners now, so we are approaching it from the other end of actually removing some of the workload. We are addressing An Coimisiún Pleanála and huge strides have been made.

That makes common sense and it will take a lot of the workload off the planners. I am well aware many of them are very stressed with what they have to go through. Have objections and judicial reviews been looked at and can something be put in place there to stop some of those going on, bar their really needing to go forward?

Our judicial review system is an essential part of our courts system and our courts system is an essential part of our democracy under the umbrella of our Constitution. The nature of judicial reviews has changed in recent years. They have moved away from general principles into being more of a trawling exercise by some people. There is also the length of time appeals to An Coimisiún Pleanála or judicial reviews were taking in and of themselves. This was becoming a justification for bringing an appeal for no other reason than to delay. We have tried to speed it up. Within judicial reviews and planning applications made under the 2024 Act, this legislation significantly tightened up what is known as the locus standi. The grounds under which people can take a challenge are now much tighter. There is a need to have an actual interest. There has also been the removal of the appeal to the Court of Appeal and the removal of the opportunity for someone taking a judicial review to amend their hand, to change the grounds, during the case. There is also a requirement for people to have put their best foot forward and to have exercised all the various opportunities before ending up in court. We are now examining applying the same rules to decisions made under the 2000 Act.

We are preserving the opportunity for people to be able to take judicial reviews, which is essential in any democracy, but also tightening up the basis on which this can be done. We are also removing the leave stage. Where the judge finds there is an issue, this does not mean the planning application is struck out. It simply goes back for remittal to allow it to be seen whether that particular issue can be amended or fixed, rather than everybody having to go back to the very start again, thereby reducing the costs. This retains that democratic balance while ensuring the courts are not being weaponised and there is efficiency in the system.
Some 300,000 houses will be built before 2030. I really welcome this and it is fantastic. Are we going to have the workforce in this country to deliver those houses?

There are certain challenges with the workforce but modern methods of construction are essential here. This is the case in terms of 2D modern methods of construction, and we are increasing the use of this approach very significantly and trying to increase the use of 3D volumetric units. Increasing the use of modern methods of construction is critical. I am always explaining that I grew up in a family of tradespeople and I would have been on sites when I was younger. When we go onto a site now, it is noticeable how clean it is. This is because a lot of the blockwork uses modern methods of construction as well and some are also starting to develop 3D printing.
I agree with the Minister, but skilled, trained workers are going to be needed in future, and we need to look more to apprenticeships and getting people involved in the trade.

I could not agree more with the Deputy. I think there was a trend back in the 1990s and 2000s, and certainly when I was going to school, when apprenticeships were not given the respect they deserved. They continued to be given respect in other European countries, but not in Ireland. I think this has been recognised and the skills needed in apprenticeships are extraordinary. That respect for apprenticeships has now returned. It is an amazing career and one that can be taken anywhere in the world if people want to travel. People who do apprenticeships will always have a job and these jobs are impregnable to artificial intelligence. I encourage anyone to take up what is a very good career.
I thank the Minister and compliment him on the good work he is doing.

I want to go back and ask about the one-stage approval process. There is a line in the plan that refers to the one-stage approval process being implemented where appropriate. In this regard, will the Minister outline, insofar as is possible, how many of the total number of developments for social housing going through at the moment are going through the one-stage approval process? What is the average length of time from application to departmental approval with the one-stage approval process?

I do not have that detail in front of me but I will get it for the Deputy. Some developments will be going through the existing one-stage process and there is the four-stage process. We want to transition local authorities into the one-stage process as quickly as possible because it is the way to maximise delivery. We will be entrusting our local authorities to deliver those homes.
Will the one-stage approval process be fully implemented by the end of this year?
I certainly expect that it will be and certainly our aim is to get it implemented by the end of the year. For me, it is absolutely crucial to drive home delivery.

Is the Minister proposing anything to address the increasing unaffordability of cost rental and affordable purchase? Is he going to look at the equity share structure or at tweaking the scheme in any way? In my city of Limerick, some of the houses in the affordable purchase schemes are going for prices well over €400,000. For the cost-rental houses, the price is up near €2,000 a month, albeit slightly below the market rate. I am concerned that, with the Residential Tenancies Board, RTB, amendment Bill is coming next year, if rents rise again, the cost-rental model will continue to become more and more unaffordable. How does the Minister propose to address this issue?

Cost rental varies across the State in terms of what is being charged, but we are keeping it all under review. I want to ensure the affordable schemes are just that: affordable and available for people.
Is the Minister concerned about cost-rental rents rising?

I am always concerned about any rents rising, and that would include where cost-rental costs may be going up. There are cost-rental units available at various rates. The key thing is that it remains at least 25% below the market rate, and this is what we aim to continue to do. Rents are rising; I do not want rents rising. They are rising too fast. The ultimate solution is maximising housing supply and that is what will get rents back down.

In relation to the delivery of social housing and turnkey units versus direct delivery, we know the majority of what the Land Development Agency has delivered and the local authorities are delivering has been coming through turnkey units. When will the body of work be complete in relation to the gearing issue that is there for approved housing bodies, AHBs? What measures is the Minister going to take under this housing plan to wean local authorities and approved housing bodies off turnkey units as a mode of delivery? When I talk to people from local authorities and approved housing bodies at the moment, I know it is easier for them to go down the turnkey route because it is significantly less risky.

It is easier to go down the turnkey route, but I want those bodies doing direct delivery. There are two different types of turnkey approaches. One is forward-funded and the other is actually turnkey, where the houses are built and potentially sold on the private market and a local authority or AHB moves in to purchase them. I am not as concerned about forward-funding, but it is still not ideal. Whether it is local authorities or affordable housing bodies, I prefer them to identify their own sites and to be doing the designing, planning and building themselves. That is where we want to get to. This is why our new affordable housing body strategy is all aimed towards getting to that point too.
It is going to require a transition. It is not something that can be done-----

I want to ask another question because I have only ten seconds left. On the fund the Minister is introducing to get families out of long-term homelessness, is he planning to bring forward additional measures to deal with single adults in homelessness? We know they comprise the biggest group of non-movers, so to speak.

They are. It can be quite challenging for single people. For the moment, my focus is very much on families, including families in emergency accommodation, because the impact of homelessness, although quite severe on everybody, is severe on children in particular. It affects their development.

Regarding single people, the challenge has been that there simply have not been enough one-bedroom and even two-bedroom houses built by our local authorities. That should be addressed by the local authorities at the level of planning permissions, and also through county development plans. We are working with the local authorities. We are considering mandating them, if necessary, to build the housing they need in their areas. In Dublin, for example, we have a shortage of four- and five-bedroom houses. We also have a shortage of one-bedroom houses. In many cases for single persons, appropriately sized properties, be they one-bedroom or two-bedroom, are simply not being built. We need more of them. Directing or mandating local authorities is an essential part of that.
I will ask a couple of questions before the next round.

Is it possible to have an audit in local authorities to show how many one-bedroom units there are? It seems that two-bedroom houses are being built where there is not a great need for them. I realise there is some need for them but, in the vast majority of cases, two-bedroom houses are occupied by single people or couples. Would it be more cost-effective to deliver more one-bedroom units than two-bedroom units?

One of the members made the point that some local authority areas had a scheme to allow downsizing or right-sizing. I am referring to a scheme whereby those in three-bedroom semi-detached houses and whose children have gone, or who may be widowed, could transfer to smaller properties. That would free up family homes. Coming from a rural area, I hear about many elderly people living in three- or four-bedroom houses, maybe out the country, who would love to move into a one- or two-bedroom house in the village. They wish to either sell the family home or leave it to some of the younger generation as a family home.

I happened to be over in Brussels yesterday at a European People’s Party event on housing. There is a housing crisis in most countries in Europe although we do not hear about it here, naturally enough. I found it very interesting to see the different ways countries were addressing it. As a committee, we have asked the secretariat to consider, particularly having regard to best practice around Europe, whether we could identify other ways we feel might make a difference. Is there much discussion among ministers for housing of the various EU countries about coming up with alternative ideas that might not obtain here?

There is. I was in Copenhagen a few weeks ago and met various ministers from across Europe, including the ministers for housing from France, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Slovenia and Denmark. There is now a housing crisis right across Europe. Certain decisions have been made by the EU. Previously, there was no Commissioner for housing and the impact on housing delivery may not have been considered in making decisions. We now have a Commissioner for housing, Dan Jørgensen, and he is publishing his plan on 16 December. We are looking forward to it. We have had an input, as have various ministers for housing across Europe. Housing delivery and infrastructure have very much become an acute Europe-wide problem. I met the French and Dutch ministers for housing to discuss solutions. In many ways, our schemes in Ireland are far more advanced than many in other countries, and countries are seeking to adopt some of them. Addressing this at EU level is crucial, as is very much recognised. I look forward to the publication of the housing plan from the Commissioner.

I thank the Minister. I am conscious of time and want to allow Senator McCarthy to contribute. Every time he came in, he had to leave for a vote in the Seanad, so I am going to allow him to contribute now.
I thank the Cathaoirleach.

I thank the Minister. The reason I am running in and out is because we are voting on the Finance Bill. Without the finance, it will not be possible to build the houses. I appreciate the presence of the Minister and his team today.

The Government is committed to building 300,000 homes and eradicating homelessness by 2030. I visited the Houses in 2016 when Simon Coveney was the Minister. I was sort of innocent and these matters were very new to me. It was agreed that homelessness would be eradicated by 2020. We have had a perfect storm, and in this regard the current Minister has said there is a housing crisis across Europe. I presume that with migration and everything added to it, we have a big issue. We are trying to sort it and I am supportive of the Minister in that regard.

Regarding the national targets sent to local authorities, is the Minister satisfied that they have been translated at council level? The feedback I am getting is that not many councils have advanced to the Department meaningful numbers regarding rezoning capacity.

Rezoning is ongoing in local authorities across the country. We have given them a breakdown, under the new national planning framework, of what we need each of them to be able to deliver. Some are moving quite quickly but others are not moving as quickly as I would want them to or as they need to. I will be writing to every local authority this week to remind them of their duty. While the failure to deliver on housing may appear in national figures, it happens if each local authority fails to do what we need it to do. Some are very proactive in delivering social and affordable housing and facilitating private housing delivery, while some may not be.

The local authorities are our housing authorities. The Department of housing does not build houses; it delivers houses through our housing authorities, which are our local authorities, and the Land Development Agency and affordable housing bodies, and also by facilitating people to purchase privately. We are working with local authorities to deliver the housing we need.
Is there a way to encourage local authorities that are not increasing capacity and tell them that now is the time and that the clock is ticking?

Yes. We will be highlighting the local authorities that are delivering. We have brought league tables to the Government and they have been published. We will be publishing more. The best way is for people in a county or local authority area to be able to see what their neighbours are doing and then ask why their own authority is not doing the same. The disparities between some local authorities are quite stark under various headings.
The variation is a reserved function of councillors. Through the housing plan, we will be incentivising councils, through financial supports, that meet whatever targets we need them to meet.

Planning has become complicated. Our local government task force, whose work will be concluding in the new year, is examining how we can re-empower or give additional powers and supports to councillors. On that, we have gone too far in the other way. I want to see the role of councillors strengthened.

Let me refer to one area in which the Minister knows I am involved: homelessness. I am involved with an approved housing body. When I appeared before a joint committee of the Houses of the Oireachtas in 2016, I brought with me a guy who had been given three houses, including apartments, by the State.

It all went wrong for him. He ended up losing the key, it was boarded up, he burned one, etc. He gave his story here. He had addiction and mental health issues, so without the proper supports, we could be giving him houses for the rest of his life. The plan is to have 12,000 new social homes per year. What portion of those 12,000 will be ring-fenced for people exiting homelessness and people with complex needs? How will the Minister guarantee that local authorities will ring-fence them for those people? If not, we are going to be constantly giving houses to the same people. They need the supports. It all has to work together.

Absolutely. Senator McCarthy has identified a very important point around homelessness in the sense that we cannot address the issue as if homeless people are a homogenous group. When we go down to a granular level, we have a lot of families becoming homeless as a result of notices to quit, for example, but there are situations where this is legitimately used. We also have people who have addiction or mental health issues and they need supports when they are put into their first homes. In some cases, they do not need extensive supports, but where they do, they can be put in transition homes as well, which means they can leave homelessness and go into safe and secure homes.

Another category in this regard is young people who are leaving care. Tusla and the HSE have a vital role to play for individuals who are going through their own trauma, whether it is addiction, mental health issues or leaving care. Supports must be there to help them to go into a secure home and also to sustain them there, which is crucial. I met Cork City Council today on that very point. I asked what more help it needed from us but also from other Departments. We have a meeting of the Cabinet subcommittee on homelessness coming up next week. We will have various Ministers, for example, the Minister for children, the Minister for Health and also the Minister for Social Protection. We will look at how we can ensure that the additional supports that are needed for the cohort of people who are homeless are being provided and are in place.

The Minister mentioned young people coming out of care. Four years ago, I opened a centre in Naas, called Jigginstown Manor, in connection with Kildare County Council. The council really bought into it from day 1. It has been tremendously successful. We had 84 young people through it and we got them into education, apprenticeships, etc.

We run the Lighthouse café in Dublin. We have anywhere between 250 to 500 people there every day. If the Minister came in this evening with €500,000, it would not solve the issue for those people unless they had the proper supports. I appreciate the Minister being on the same page.

I will put ten minutes on the clock for the discussion so we will finish prior to 5.15 p.m. We will let members back in. I am conscious that Deputy Gould did not get a second chance to speak, so I will him in.
Do I have ten minutes?
No, it is ten minutes in total. I will give the Deputy three minutes.
In his briefing, the Minister outlines how there is €100 million in capital funding to help families exit emergency accommodation. How many houses does he think €100 million will buy?
It will vary depending on the location. If we buy a house in Dublin, it will be considerably more expensive.
How many, on average?

I do not want to put a figure on it. The €100 million is available and it is being used by, for example, the Dublin Region Homeless Executive, DRHE, and others to ensure that we get the accommodation we need to get people long-term accommodation. I will not get into numbers. It is a complex matrix. The price varies depending on whether it is a house in Cork, Wexford or Dublin.

If we divide €100 million by 31 local authorities and we say that, on average, a house costs €250,000 - but it would be a lot more in Dublin, so I am really going on the low side – that is 13 houses per local authority.

I am not sure if I gave the exact figures, so I just want to correct the record in regard to the information we got from Cork City Council last night. Two families were four or more years on the housing list – that is four Christmases - three families were three Christmases on the housing list; 21 were on the list for their second Christmas, and there were another 67. Some 93 families in Cork city are homeless. That is people who have been consecutively homeless; some people go on and off the list. A total of 496 individuals have been consecutively homeless. Other people go in and out of homelessness. The Minister is giving Cork City Council 13 houses and expecting that to help families exit emergency accommodation. He is giving huge tax breaks to developers who are building apartments that are already built or in the process of being built. The developers would not have started to build the apartments unless they were viable. The Government is giving massive tax breaks and then it is giving a drop in the ocean to help people in emergency accommodation.

I am reading from page 6 of the Minister's document. The sum of €100 million is nearly like an insult to people who are homeless. The homeless figures have been going up non-stop for ten years and the Minister expects 13 homes per local authority to solve that. I invite the Minister or his Department to estimate how many homes the €100 million will deliver. I reckon the number will be less than what I have outlined.

Moving on to page 7 of the briefing, the Minister talks about the derelict sites tax. Why is the levy not starting on 1 January? Local authorities have been collecting information for 35 years. There is a lot of information there now. I know it is not complete, but expecting to wait another year suggests the Minister is letting land hoarders get away. That is wrong.
The Minister might answer all the questions together. We will give one minute to each member and then the Minister can sum up.

I will be brief. I spoke to the Minister before about funding for the regeneration of some of our oldest and poorest quality council flat complexes, particularly in Dublin. At the time, the discussion was that the Department was insisting on increased density to release capital funding. My understanding is that that position has now changed but the Department is still insisting that there can be no reduction in density. Given that this is some of the worst rental accommodation in the State, particularly the flat complexes that date from the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s, I appeal to the Minister to state that there should be no density requirement. The homes should be brought up to contemporary standards, and it is fine if additional density can be provided. Does the Minister have an update on the Department's position on these urgent regenerations and, if not, can he provide it by way of writing to the committee before the Christmas recess? There are some in Cork as well but the bulk of them are in inner city Dublin.

I will focus on the capacity of the construction sector, which Deputy Cooney touched on earlier as well, and modern methods of construction. There is a specific scheme, built to innovate, by Enterprise Ireland. Is it intended that we would look at that scheme and expand it or revise it to try and incentivise greater use of modern methods of construction? The construction sector is very much up for it. It is great that we are showing leadership in the plan as well in regard to social and affordable properties where our aim is to have 25% of them constructed through modern methods of construction. That is important. Is the built to innovate scheme something that is in the Minister's line of sight to try to look at how we can expand it further?

I want to ask about the role of the LDA in the new housing plan and what specific additional powers, if any, the Minister is going to grant it in the area of land management in particular to stop it having to negotiate bilaterally with individual State entities?

If we buy a group of houses that are run down, as happens on all main streets and offshoots of main streets, it is mind-blowing to think how many times the council goes up and down to Dublin to communicate with the Department in order to get the approval to go ahead. Surely, there is a better way to do it. I gave my life as a councillor requesting information year in and year out, not monthly, on how far we have advanced. I wanted to find out where we were and then we could go on to the next step. That is one area where the Minister could get a huge delivery from local authorities. It is not all the fault of the local authorities. For years, as councillors, we identified the sites. For example, we might ask the council to buy two derelict houses.
It takes between seven and nine years to get two families into those. That is crazy. There should be two families in them within 15 months.
What other measures can be put in place to make more affordable housing available for young people who are crying out for houses? Unfortunately, they cannot get into the housing market.

I turn to Deputy Gould's point. As he knows full well, the €100 million is only one measure. It adds to the €50 million this year already. It is only one measure to get people out of homelessness. Cork allocated 722 homes last year. Social housing and void allocation are also critical to getting people out of homeless accommodation. There is also tenant in situ, second-hand acquisitions and HAP. It is only one measure being used. In particular, we find with families who have been in homelessness for a considerable time that there may be particular situations for those families. That is why we have created this fund to provide an additional solution to the many other solutions in place. Last year, we had record exits from homelessness and also record preventions. Huge work is being done by local authorities to prevent families going into homelessness.

I turn to other issues. Everything about what I am trying to do is about simplification. I agree with Deputy Aird that we need to speed up our systems. Trusting local authorities is key. That is why I am using the single-stage process as well. Deputy McGrath mentioned modern methods of construction, MMC. We are working with the Minister for Enterprise, Tourism and Employment, Deputy Burke, and Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research Innovation and Science and the Ministers, Deputy Lawless, and their respective Departments to ensure MMC is being used. That innovation model is critical for smaller medium-size developers to be able to adapt the new skills being developed. The technologies being used are crucial.

Deputy Sheehan asked about the role of the LDA within the housing plan. The Government has agreed to massively increase the scope of the LDA and its geographical region. We have also secured additional funding for the LDA. I see a big increase in the role of the LDA in coming years.

Deputy Cooney spoke about more affordable housing. It is about maximising the different schemes for starter homes to ensure there are no gaps, people have the opportunity to use the affordable measures and homes are delivered through supply, so people get the benefit of them.

Rather than delaying the committee further, can we get a note from the Minister's officials on the current position of the Department with respect to the capital funding for flat complex regeneration of social housing?
I will do that.
Will that be forwarded to the Deputy or the committee?
If it is sent to the committee we can all have it. It is better practice.

I thank the Minister and his officials for assisting the committee. I know we will be seeing some of them again later in the week and next week to discuss this important matter, the housing plan. We will briefly suspend ahead of our discussion of the planning and development regulations 2025.

summary.i: Sitting suspended at 5.14 p.m. and resumed at 5.20 p.m.

debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: Planning and Development (Exempted Development (Act of 2000)) Regulations 2025: Discussion

speech.p: The Planning and Development (Exempted Development (Act of 2000)) Regulations 2025 have been referred to the committee for consideration. I am pleased to have the opportunity to consider the regulations with the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage, Deputy Browne, and his officials. The opening statement has been circulated to members. Do we have agreement to publish it? That is agreed. I ask the Minister to read out his short opening statement.

speech.from: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Heritage (Deputy James Browne)
speech.p: I thank the Cathaoirleach for affording me the opportunity to present to him and the committee these proposed planning regulations on behalf of my colleague, the Minister of State, Deputy Cummins.

The Planning and Development (Exempted Development (Act of 2000)) Regulations 2025 amend the Planning and Development Regulations 2001, as already amended by the 2001 regulations, by extending until 31 December 2028 the provisions for change of use from commercial to residential in vacant properties under Article 10(6) of the 2001 regulations. This ensures individuals can avail of the exemption without fear of enforcement as the current provision expires on 31 December 2025.

I note the context of these regulations was discussed and approved by the committee on 14 October alongside exemptions regarding agriculture. I advise the committee that the agricultural elements have been removed from this version as an environmental assessment is ongoing regarding those proposals and will take a little more time to conclude. It is important these change of use regulations are in place before the end of this year so they are being relaid separately to ensure continuity and that the exemption for change of use from commercial to residential is not allowed to expire. Once complete, the Minister of State, Deputy Cummins, will relay the agricultural regulations before the Oireachtas and will appear before the committee.

With regard to the change of use regulations before us today, the Government is committed to measures that support the delivery of housing units. By extending the exemptions for a further three years, it is hoped more people will consider availing of the exemption and change the use of vacant properties from commercial to residential, thereby increasing the number of housing units available in the State within the next three years.

The draft regulation is being prepared under the Planning and Development Act 2000, as amended. When new exempted development regulations are made under the Planning and Development Act 2024, the provisions regarding change of use from commercial to residential will be maintained. It is important to note the planning exemptions are removed where works would materially affect an protected structure or an environmental assessment or appropriate assessment is required. Planning permission is required in these instances.

I commend the draft regulations to the committee. Having regard to the need to support the delivery of housing, the regulations are intended to give certainty. If, further to today's presentation to the committee, the draft regulations are approved by positive resolution of both Houses of the Oireachtas, as required under the Planning Act, they will come into force as soon as they are signed by the Minister of State, Deputy Cummins.

The role of the committee in scrutinising exempted development regulations is a really important one. In the long time I have been on this committee, we have always facilitated Ministers and taken a constructive role. These regulations are no different but what has happened with the first module of exempted development regulations is unprecedented in my time in the Oireachtas. I was hoping the Minister might address it. Given its absence from his opening statement, I will ask him to address it.

We were given a set of exempted development regulations and there was significant discussion of the environmental impacts of those. I, Deputy McGrath and others raised questions. We were told the environmental assessment was ongoing and we queried that but to facilitate the Minister of State, we then approved the regulations. The Minister of State wrote back to us some weeks later asking us to do something which is not legal. We know that because the committee had to get legal advice on the matter. We were asked to effectively overturn a decision of the Oireachtas that approved the original set of regulations. That should not have happened. I do not understand why it happened and I hope the Minister can provide an explanation.

Now the original regulations, which we spend considerable time discussing, have been split and more committee time is being taken up. Given this is the first of a series of modules, the question I have is why the original cluster of regulations was brought to us before the environmental assessment was complete. We now know it should not have been done. The environmental assessment has clearly raised some issues that mean the regulations removed in relation to slurry tanks and animal shelters will have to be amended. Why was the committee asked to do something not in accordance with the rules? The request did not come from the Minister; however, the Minister of State, Deputy Cummins, is one of his junior Ministers. Ultimately, the Minister is responsible for the overall direction of the Department. What guarantee can he give the committee that it will not happen again? I say this as someone who comes to these regulations in a constructive manner. Can the Minister give us an updated timeframe for the further rounds of regulations? They have obviously been delayed in part by this.

For a committee to be asked to do something that is not in line with Standing Orders and to have to seek legal advice to clarify that is quite unprecedented. I want an assurance from the Minister that something like that will not happen again, particularly given how important these kinds of regulations are.

I thank the Deputy. Everyone always intends to do these things in the appropriate manner. I understand there was some difficulty in terms of the regulations and how they were approached. Clarity was sought in relation to the procedure. I assure the Deputy that is never what is intended. Certainly, it will always be intended that appropriate procedures are followed.
Does the Minister accept, in this instance, that was not the case and that is not a good situation for any of us to be in?

Our intention is always to ensure appropriate procedures are followed. The regulations were relaid because the committee came to a decision. Anything that has happened will form the basis for future approaches to regulations.

I have two final questions then. Does the Minister think it was a mistake for that first round of regulations to be brought to the committee before the environmental assessment was complete? Can he give us a guarantee that we will not have a repeat of this with the other modules that are coming through and that we will be able to deal with them in an appropriate manner?

I have no doubt the Minister of State, Deputy Cummins, will be able to address at a future date why he took a particular approach. I cannot get into the Minister of State's mind in relation to it. It is always the intention to ensure that procedure is followed. If a decision is taken that it was not the correct procedure, then obviously everyone will act accordingly.

You are the senior Minister. They are your juniors. I appreciate you do not control everything they do, but you have oversight of it. Do you think it was appropriate for the regulations to be brought to this committee prior to the completion of the environmental assessment? Can you guarantee the committee will not be put in the position it was put in the last time, that regulations will be brought to us in an appropriate manner and that we will be asked to deal with them in accordance with Standing Orders?
It always was and will be the intention to bring regulations to the committee in compliance with the appropriate procedures. That is what will always be the intention.

Where that does not happen, I ask the Minister to undertake to ensure we do not have a repeat of such an instance. In my ten years on the committee, we have dealt with lots of exempted development regulations but have never had regulations presented, then withdrawn, then a request made of the committee to override a decision of the Oireachtas and then had to have repeat sessions of the committee to deal with these at a time when the planning section of the Department is already overstretched.

I appreciate the committee has a huge workload. I will make every effort to ensure any regulations brought before the committee are in accordance with procedures. If regulations are brought that are not in accordance with procedures, that is not intentional. Every effort is made. The committee has to reach its own decision and we will act accordingly.

I welcome this extension to the provision for the change of use for vacant properties from commercial to residential. It is important. I have seen at first-hand where vacant properties, whether they are pubs, former pubs, shops or offices, have been converted into residential units and provided good accommodation for individuals and families. It is very important that certainty is given. The extensions of three years is welcome. As we know, the original provision was to come to an end this year. I welcome this measure and thank the Minister and his team for bringing this before the committee. I commend it.

I concur with the Deputy's comments in support of the measure. It is needed. There are certain timelines required because of the end of the year and the agricultural regulations. That is the intention.

I welcome the extension. I understand there are challenges from a planning perspective as to how this change is affecting the character of our commercial streets in towns and villages and would not be in line with what the planners would consider the proper planning and sustainable development of an area. Could there be some mechanism within the legislation that would allow the planning section of a local authority to apply some brakes to this extension if it was felt to be needed? That might be to ensure that a whole street does not become totally residential without any commercial units.

There are guidelines for the use of the exemptions. I will take another look at them and ask the Minister of State, Deputy Cummins, to do the same. They should not be allowed where there are conflicts with development plan objectives, so there is a certain amount of scope there for the planners. This is always about balancing the local authority's development plan and ensuring consistency across the country with respect to who can apply and when permission can be granted. Those matters should not be in conflict. We will engage with the local authorities and planners.

That concludes the discussion of the matter. No other member is indicating. I propose that the committee request the clerk to the committee to inform the Dáil and Seanad accordingly. Is that agreed? Agreed.

debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: Messages to Dáil and Seanad

speech.p: In accordance with Dáil Standing Order 103, the following message will be sent to the Dáil:
The Joint Committee on Housing, Local Government and Heritage has completed its consideration of the following order in draft:
Planning and Development (Exempted Development (Act of 2000)) Regulations 2025
copies of which were laid before Dáil Éireann on 27 November 2025.
In accordance with Seanad Standing Order 79, the following message will be sent to the Seanad:
The Joint Committee on Housing, Local Government and Heritage has completed its consideration of the following order in draft:
Planning and Development (Exempted Development (Act of 2000)) Regulations 2025
copies of which were laid before Seanad Éireann on 27 November 2025.
I thank the Minister and his officials for assisting us with our consideration of the matter.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee went into private session at 5.33 p.m. and adjourned at 5.38 p.m. until 3 p.m. on Tuesday, 16 December 2025.
